facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 18 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 14, 1967 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 307 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 18 of 1968. Appeal by Special leave from the judgment and order dated April 14,,1967 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 307 of 1965.

facts.text: The appellant was represented by M. Tarkunde, Urmila Kapoor and R. K. Khanna.

anchor.surface_text: M. Tarkunde, Urmila Kapoor and R. K. Khanna, for the appellant.

facts.text: The respondent was represented by V. Gupte and M. V. Goswami.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte and M. V. Goswami, for the respondent.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the Allahabad High Court

facts.text: The facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are number in dispute. The appellant had been occupying a shop in Mathura belonging to the respondent from a very long time,

facts.text: The appellant had been occupying a shop in Mathura belonging to the respondent from a very long time at a monthly rental of Rs. 18.37.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had been occupying a shop in Mathura belonging to the respondent from a very long time, at a monthly rental of Rs. 18.37.

facts.text: In 1962 the respondent wanted to construct rooms on the upper storey of the shop for his own residence.

anchor.surface_text: In 1962 the respondent wanted to companystruct rooms on the upper Storey of the shop for his own residence. This companystruction companyld possibly be made only if the appellant vacated the shop for some period.

facts.text: Construction could possibly be made only if the appellant vacated the shop for some period.

anchor.surface_text: This companystruction companyld possibly be made only if the appellant vacated the shop for some period. On June 4, 1962, the appellant and the respondent entered into an agreement .

facts.text: On June 4, 1962, the appellant and the respondent entered into an agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On June 4, 1962, the appellant and the respondent entered into an agreement . After reciting the above facts it was agreed that the shop would be.

facts.text: The shop is bearing No. 1/2C, situate at Tilakdwar.

anchor.surface_text: On this day the second party has withdrawn his possession from the shop bearing No. 1/2C, situate at Tilakdwar, and has given the same to the first party.

facts.text: On the day of agreement, the second party (appellant) withdrew possession from the shop and gave it to the first party (respondent).

anchor.surface_text: On this day the second party has withdrawn his possession from the shop bearing No. 1/2C, situate at Tilakdwar, and has given the same to the first party.

facts.text: The first party (respondent) shall get the shop constructed within thirty days and hand over possession to the second party (appellant).

anchor.surface_text: The first party shall get the shop companystructed within thirty days and would then hand over the possession of the same to the second party.

facts.text: Monthly rent is Rs. 18-6-0 including house tax and water tax.

anchor.surface_text: At present a sum of Rs. 18-6-0 per mensem, which includes house tax and water tax, is being paid by the second Party to the first party as rent.

facts.text: After construction, rent remains the same amount.

anchor.surface_text: After the companystruction of the shop, the first party shall be entitled to get the same, amount as rent from the second party.

facts.text: All sections of the U.P. Rent Control and Eviction Act shall be fully applicable to this house.

anchor.surface_text: All the sections of the U.P. Rent Control and Eviction Act shall be fully applicable to this house.

facts.text: The first party shall in no case be entitled to derive benefits from it as the property built after 1-1-51.

anchor.surface_text: The first party shall in numbercase be entitled to derive benefits from it as the property built after 1-1-51.

facts.text: After construction, the appellant resumed possession of the shop.

anchor.surface_text: After the companystruction had been made and the appellant had resumed his possession of the shop the appellant offered rent to the respondent but the latter did number accept the same.

facts.text: The appellant offered rent to the respondent but the respondent did not accept it.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant offered rent to the respondent but the latter did number accept the same. Ultimately lie deposited the rent from April 1, 1962 to July 31, 1963 in companyrt under s. 7 C of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant deposited rent from April 1, 1962 to July 31, 1963 in court under s. 7C of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately lie deposited the rent from April 1, 1962 to July 31, 1963 in companyrt under s. 7 C of the Act. The respondent served a numberice April 20, 1963 apparently under the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act purporting to terminate the tenancy of the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent served notice on April 20, 1963 under Transfer of Property Act to terminate tenancy of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent served a numberice April 20, 1963 apparently under the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act purporting to terminate the tenancy of the appellant. This was followed by a suit which the respondent filed for ejectment of the appellant and for arrears of rent, damages etc.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit for ejectment of appellant, arrears of rent, damages etc.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a suit which the respondent filed for ejectment of the appellant and for arrears of rent, damages etc.

facts.text: Munsif dismissed the suit holding appellant entitled to protection of s.3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsif dismissed the suit holding that the appellant was entitled to the protection companyferred by s. 3 of the Act which was applicable.

facts.text: District Judge on appeal took contrary view, decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge, on appeal, took the companytrary view and decreed the suit.

facts.text: High Court affirmed judgment of District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court affirmed the judgment of the District Judge.

facts.text: High Court held respondent entitled to rely on s.1A of the Act, appellant not given benefit of s.3.

anchor.surface_text: It was held, inter-alia, that the, respondent was, entitled to rely on s. 1 A of the Act and the appellant companyld number be given the benefit of s. 3.

facts.text: Tenancy between appellant and respondent governed by the Act prior to reconstruction.

anchor.surface_text: Now there can be numbermanner of doubt that the tenancy between the appellant and the respondent was governed by the provisions of the Act prior to the reconstruction of the premises.

facts.text: Reconstruction made after agreement in 1962, buildings constructed within terms of s.1-A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to have been accepted that when the respondent made the re-construction after the agreement mentioned above in 1962 the buildings came to be companystructed within the terms of s. 1-A of the Act

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored trial court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court is set aside and that of the trial companyrt restored. The appellant will be entitled to his companyts in this, companyrt.

issues.text: whether the appellant, who was the tenant, was entitled to the benefit of s. 3 of U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: It will have to be decided whether it was open to the respondent to give up the benefit of this provision or waive it by means of an agreement of the nature which was entered into between the appellant and the respondent in June 1962.

issues.text: whether S. 1-A was merely in the nature of an exemption in favour of the landlords, with regard to the buildings constructed after January 1, 1951 and conferred a benefit on them which they could give up or waive by agreement or contractual arrangement and whether the consideration or object of such an agreement would not be lawful within the meaning of s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act

arguments.claim: the Act was enacted for affording protection to the tenants against eviction except in the manner provided by the Act ... legislature was conscious of the fact that the Act might retard ... pace of construction of new buildings ... saving provision in s. 1-A seems to have been inserted

anchor.surface_text: According to the preamble on the cessation of the applicability of sub-rule 2 of rule 81 of the Defence of India Rules after September 30, 1946 it was considered expedient owing to the shortage of accommodation in the State of Uttar Pradesh to provide for the continuance during limited period of powers to control the letting and the rent of accommodation and to prevent the eviction of tenants therefrom. Section 3 imposed restrictions on eviction.

arguments.claim: S. 1-A was merely in the nature of an exemption in favour of the landlords ... conferred a benefit on them which they could give up or waive by agreement or contractual arrangement and ... consideration or object of such an agreement would not be unlawful within the meaning of s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act

anchor.surface_text: The essential question that has to be resolved is whether S. 1-A was merely in the nature of an exemption in favour of the landlords, with regard to the buildings constructed after January 1, 1951 and conferred a benefit on them which they could give up or waive by agreement or contractual arrangement and whether the consideration or object of such an agreement would not be lawful within the meaning of s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act.

arguments.claim: every one has a right to waive and to agree to waive the advantage of a law or rule made solely for the benefit and protection of the individual in his private capacity which may be dispensed with without infringing any public right or public policy

anchor.surface_text: The general principle is that every one has a right to waive and to agree to waive the advantage of a law or rule made solely for the benefit and protection of the individual in his private capacity which may be dispensed with without infringing any public right or public policy.

arguments.claim: any person can enter into a binding contract to waive the benefits conferred upon him by an Act of Parliament ... unless ... contrary to public policy

anchor.surface_text: As a general rule, any person can enter into a binding contract to waive the benefits conferred upon him by an Act of Parliament, or, as it is said, can contract himself out of the Act, unless it can be shown that such an agreement is in the circumstances of the particular case contrary to public policy.

arguments.claim: consideration or object of the agreement ... is of such a nature that it would defeat the provision of any law [s.1A]

anchor.surface_text: Reliance has been placed mainly on the next part of the section, namely, that it is of such a nature that it would defeat the provision of any law and in the present case it would be s. 1-A of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: no prohibition in s.1A, performance does not entail transgression of law

arguments.claim: the words if permitted it would defeat the provisions of any law in s. 23 ... refer to performance of an agreement which necessarily entails the transgression of the Provisions of any law ... performance is impossible except by disobedience of law

anchor.surface_text: We concur with the view expressed in Neminath Appayya Hanumannavar v. Jamboorao Satappa Kocheri that the words if permitted it would defeat the provisions of any law in s. 23 of the Contract Act refer to performance of an agreement which necessarily entails the transgression of the Provisions of any law.

arguments.claim: s. 1-A was meant for the benefit of owners of buildings ... no bar ... in the way of his waiving ... No question of policy, much less public policy, was involved

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment s. 1-A was meant for the benefit of owners of buildings which were under erection or were constructed after January 1, 1951. If a particular owner did not wish to avail of the benefit of that section there was no bar created by it in the way of his waiving, or giving up or abandoning the advantage or the benefit contemplated by the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurs with precedent interpreting s.23 to require necessary legal transgression for invalidity, not mere defeat of benefit.

holdings.text: s. 1-A was meant for the benefit of owners of buildings which were under erection or were constructed after January 1, 1951. anchor.surface_text: In our judgment s. 1-A was meant for the benefit of owners of buildings which were under erection or were constructed after January 1, 1951. If a particular owner did not wish to avail of the benefit of that section there was no bar created by it in the way of his waiving, or giving up or abandoning the advantage or the benefit contemplated by the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text lacks prohibition; provision encourages construction via optional exemption for private benefit.

holdings.text: No question of policy, much less public policy, was involved and such a benefit or advantage could always be waived. That is what was done in the present case and we are unable to agree with the High Court that the consideration or object of the agreement entered into between the parties in June 1962 was unlawful in view of s. 23 of the Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: No question of policy, much less public policy, was involved and such a benefit or advantage could always be waived. That is what was done in the present case and we are unable to agree with the High Court that the consideration or object of the agreement entered into between the parties in June 1962 was unlawful in view of s. 23 of the Contract Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement waives private statutory benefit without legal transgression or public policy violation; applies waiver doctrine and s.23.

holdings.text: the appellant was entitled to the benefit of s. 3 of U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court is set aside and that of the trial court restored. The appellant will be entitled to his costs in this court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid waiver restores application of Act including s.3 protection; trial court judgment restored reversing High Court denial.

precedents.cited_proposition: the words 'if permitted it would defeat the provisions of any law' in s. 23 of the Contract Act refer to performance of an agreement which necessarily entails the transgression of the provisions of any law

anchor.surface_text: The following observations of Lord Wright in Vita Food Products Incorporated v. Unus Company Ltd. 1   in Liquidation  are numbereworthy in this companynection Nor must it be forgotten that the rule by which companytracts number expressly forbidden by statute or declared to be void are in proper cases nullified for disobedience to a statute is a rule of public policy only, and public policy understood in a wider sense may at times be better served by refusing to nullify a bargain save on serious and sufficient grounds.

precedents.case_name: Vita Food Products Incorporated v. Unus Company Ltd. in Liquidation
precedents.cited_proposition: the rule by which contracts not expressly forbidden by statute or declared to be void are nullified for disobedience to a statute is a rule of public policy only, and public policy may at times be better served by refusing to nullify a bargain save on serious and sufficient grounds

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment s. 1-A was meant for the benefit of owners of buildings which were under erection or were constructed after January 1, 1951. If a particular owner did not wish to avail of the benefit of that section there was no bar created by it in the way of his waiving, or giving up or abandoning the advantage or the benefit contemplated by the section.
